facts.text: The assessee is a partnership firm which ran a sugar mill at Cawnpore and was engaged in the conversion of gur into sugar.
Relevant assessment year 1942-43, account year being October 1, 1940, to September 30, 1941.
Assessee submitted a return of income; Income-tax Officer made assessment on November 30, 1944.

Income-tax Officer added Rs. 63,954 being market value of goods in process of conversion from gur into sugar (7,956 maunds closing stock minus 850 maunds opening stock = 7,106 maunds at Rs. 9 per maund); this stock not included in return.

Income-tax Officer added back Rs. 76,836 wrongly shown as expenditure for excise duty; sales relating to this duty were in preceding year; assessee maintains mercantile system of accounting, so duty should be debited in preceding year.
Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner (AAC) against both additions; AAC rejected appeal on July 8, 1946.

AAC issued notice under section 28(3) on July 5, 1946, to show cause why penalty under section 28(1)(c) should not be imposed for concealing particulars or furnishing inaccurate particulars re: stock of 7,106 maunds and Rs. 76,836 excise duty.
Assessee furnished explanation on July 22, 1946; AAC rejected it and imposed penalty of Rs. 50,000 on January 21, 1947.
Assessee appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal (Tribunal) against assessment and penalty orders.

Tribunal, on August 7, 1947: reduced stock addition to Rs. 42,636 (at Rs. 6 per maund); held Rs. 76,836 not allowable in relevant year but directed adjustment as expenditure in 1941-42 under section 35.
Tribunal upheld penalty under section 28(1)(c) but reduced to Rs. 43,000.

Assessee moved Tribunal to refer three questions of law; Tribunal referred only Question No. 3: 'Whether the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was legally justified in issuing a notice under section 28... in respect of the item of Rs. 76,836?' Refused other two as findings of fact.
High Court of Allahabad, on reference under section 66(1), dated July 16, 1956, answered Question No. 3 against assessee.
Assessee applied to High Court under section 66(4) and (5) to direct Tribunal to state case on other two questions; High Court rejected.
This is an appeal by special leave from High Court judgment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was legally justified in issuing a notice under section 28 of the Income-tax Act in the circumstances of the case in respect of the item of Rs. 76,836?
Whether the High Court could direct the Tribunal under section 66(4) and (5) to state a case on questions refused by Tribunal as findings of fact?

petitioner_arguments.text: Assessee unable to show High Court's answer to referred question was incorrect.
First and third questions inter-connected; High Court should have directed Tribunal to state case on first question under section 66(4) and (5) even if Tribunal refused.

court_reasoning.text: Section 28 enables AAC to take action if person concealed particulars or furnished inaccurate particulars; AAC satisfied during appeal that assessee debited Rs. 76,836 excise duty relating to another year.
court_reasoning.key_observation: AAC within rights to issue notice under section 28 during appeal proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: Section 66(4) for completing incomplete case statements, not for compelling reference on refused questions (findings of fact); assessee should have moved under section 66(2); first question not implicit in third.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court correctly rejected petition under section 66(4) and (5).

holdings.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner legally justified in issuing notice under section 28 against assessee re: Rs. 76,836.
High Court not empowered under section 66(4) and (5) to direct reference on questions refused by Tribunal as findings of fact.

precedents_cited.relevance: Some decisions hold High Court under s66(5) may reframe questions or decide implicit points without new facts.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs assessment, penalty imposition by AAC, Tribunal references to High Court, and High Court powers on incomplete references.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; High Court's answer upheld that AAC was justified in issuing notice under section 28 re: Rs. 76,836; rejection of assessee's petition under section 66(4) and (5) upheld.

key_quotes.text: "Section 28 of the Income-tax Act in terms enables the Appellate Assistant Commissioner to take action under that section if in person has, inter alia, concealed the particulars of his income or deliberately furnished inaccurate particulars of such income."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for upholding AAC's power to issue penalty notice.

key_quotes.text: "Sub-section 4 of section 66 cannot do service for sub-section 2 thereof."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies limits of High Court's power to compel references.
